resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repositor.message: There are likely plenty of projects on PyPI with "openstack" in their distnames which aren't and never were official OpenStack deliverables. Short of threatening legal action to exercise trademark rights I don't expect we have much control over it, and I prefer to just accept that and not tell projects they need to change names when they give up OpenStack governance. The OpenStack TC doesn't have jurisdiction over what's published to PyPI, but it has been granted jurisdiction over what repositories appear in the "openstack" Git namespace on OpenDev.

While I think that this policy is needed it should also address the aspect of PYPI publication.

I think we need to mention what should happen with ownership of PYPI packages because we do not want to force people to change packages names when they fork a project in order to maintain it.

If the PYPI project has openstack in its name, I see no problem on locking it. But, if the project does not have openstack in its name, we should allow future maintainers to take ownership of the package, so they can release new versions. I guess they will agree not to remove the repository (they cannot replace or delete releases by PYPI design)

It probably is worth considering that if the intent is to reduce end user confusion that a project going from TC governance to non TC governance while publishing to the same name on eg PyPI doesn't signal that transition at all. Its a similar problem to the one with code hosting just on another platform.

While I agree that for simplicity (because updating all the code to use different names is a pain no one should endure) keeping the old name as is and moving forward is the best choice here we may want to consider what signalling of change we can expose on platforms like PyPI.
I can't decide whether this is supposed to be read with a comma or a hyphen between 'formerly' and 'official'. Could you eliminate the ambiguity by adding one of them?

Formerly official software, which left OpenStack governance with the itent of continuining outside it was in many cases
subsequently abandoned in place by its authors, creating an... * (the comma makes more sense, basically)
This sentence is hard to read because the verbs don't agree.

Suggested rewrite:

When development ceases on a source code repository, the `retirement process
<https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project>`_ is followed. This process replaces the repository's source code with a message in a ``README``file indicating the source code's new situation, abandons all open changes for the project, and sets Gerrit to reject future change proposals for review.
Consider also using 'formerly-official' here for consistency.
corresponding?
TIL
feature. Renaming these projects to move them ... *

resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repositor.message:
This, and reading up to this part, makes me feel like I have to release every repo, even repos that are misc tooling for CI that have zero deliverable value, in order to keep it in the namespace, which further increases the overhead and further increases PTL burnout.

Am I really interpreting this correctly?

Are we really heading down the more process path with the concept that everything is a releasable publishable artifact?

What in this text gives you the impression that any of these repositories need to have releases? This is entirely about retiring copies of repositories within the "openstack" Git namespace if they leave OpenStack governance (and expecting them to fork if they wish to continue development outside official OpenStack governance). It says nothing about whether or not they need to tag releases. We already follow this retirement process when development ceases on official deliverable repositories, and this would simply make it required to follow the same process for any which wish to continue development somewhere else (in a different Git namespace on OpenDev or outside OpenDev entirely).

Perhaps a re-read after some edits have been made might help. I admittedly don't see what you see there, Julia. But your interpretation may be similar to others so we want to ensure that's not the case - as Jeremy says, this is only able retiring copies of repos.

Further discussion in #openstack-infra has raised that there is currently a blind spot in this plan. There are still some repositories listed in governance for the Infrastructure team which are not in the "openstack" namespace (they've already been renamed into the "opendev" namespace). Options are to either add a carveout in the policy in case they're not removed from governance by the end of the Train cycle, assume that they will be removed from governance before then, or just interpret the requirement to follow retirement in the "openstack" namespace as implicitly meaning it's not necessary for those repos which have already been renamed out of the namespace even if they're removed from governance after the deadline (as the retirement process can't logically be applied within the "openstack" namespace for them anyway).

While the hosting software is perfectly fine with this there may be corner cases in other tooling that doesn't handle this well. I expect we'll just roll forward and fix any instances of that but worth being aware that there may be unexpected speed bumps around this.
maybe just say "new namespace, leaving historical context in Gerrit and no redirection." otherwise it's just a bit repetitive
Do we expect that most consumers of our software consume it from source directly or instead via something like PyPI or distro packages?

The concern being addressed is with consumers of the source code, so distro package maintainers and folks continuously deploying directly from revision control. Also this at least provides a warning somewhere, in the cases of primary concern where repositories leave OpenStack and then get abandoned yet their confused users continue reaching out to the OpenStack community to ask questions or attempt to file bug reports.

For indirect consumers like users of packages on PyPI or in various distros, other clues will be present (such as previous documentation URLs going away). It's also the responsibility of distro package maintainers to handle these sorts of changes on behalf of their users, and they ought to notice the next time they go to update their packages that the source code is no longer available at the same place they previously accessed it.

Also, at least for many direct or indirect users, when they go hunting down the source code hosting location to figure out where to report bugs, they should hopefully find the message we've left for them letting them know what's happened and/or where to go.
"OpenStack" taking responsible seems deliberately vague?
remove

Also, apologies that the timeframe is described in a somewhat circuitous fashion. Since we have no name for the "U" cycle yet, I'm forced to make it relative to the "Train" cycle (otherwise I fear references to an as-of-yet unnamed cycle would be even less clear).

It's meant to be a grace period for projects which are already intending to move out of OpenStack governance, so they can do so without forking if they request governance removal by the end of this cycle. This resolution itself would also not be the only notice, and in fact there's already an accompanying ML thread I sent to openstack-discuss tagged for PTLs (and others) to get their attention and feedback on the proposal. Suggestions for other means of bringing this to the attention of folks in charge of official teams in OpenStack are most welcome.

Note that as Glance is using a file store which is not shared between the infra Glance containers there will be issues with Glance working properly (the LB will round robin, so only one in three requests for the image will work).

There needs to be a shared file store of some sort, or the affinity of the glance containers for 2 of the three controllers needs to be set to 0 to prevent the containers even being built on them (so glance will only ever be served from one container).

We're looking at adding an NFS server to our gate tests for the purpose of having a shared NFS server for Glance backed by NFS and not Swift, whereas the current gate tests Glance backed by Swift.
Oh good point.  I'll default to glance_default_store=swift, since we're setting up swift anyway.

We can bump the minor version (in the context of the semantic versioning) multiple times in a single development cycle. When we have a new feature from a previous release, it is reasonable to bump the minor version (0.5.0 in this case).

If a new release contains bug fixes only, the patch version (0.4.1 in this case) would make sense.

In this case, we have new tests which means new feature(s) so 0.5.0 sounds good to me.

Will the root volume be fully detached and made available during the resize from the source to dest host? Because that would leave a window of time where the volume could be attached to another server.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/297de7fb9fbabe74b5305ef0aa82e196d5f48d5e/nova/compute/api.py#L3460

But that's not the case with ironic where we have 1:M host:node mappings. I think that would break here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/297de7fb9fbabe74b5305ef0aa82e196d5f48d5e/nova/compute/api.py#L3564
I would think we should have a new REST API microversion for this otherwise how would users with ironic instances know they can resize their server or not? It's definitely a behavior change.

Obviously you can't resize/cold migrate an ironic instance that is running on an older compute, so how would that fail? Would the API have a temporary check, removed in T, to see if it's an ironic instance and if so that the source compute host it's running on is new enough to perform this operation? Clearly we have the same issue with selecting a destination host if the operator is doing rolling upgrades and some of the compute hosts are running Rocky code. How would we solve that? Would we add some policy rule so operators can disable this operation for ironic instances until they are upgraded? Would we decorate compute node resource providers in placement with some kind of capability/trait to indicate they can resize baremetal instances and then add a pre-request placement filter to only select target nodes with that trait?

> Obviously you can't resize/cold migrate an ironic instance that is running on an older compute, so how would that fail?

Without any changes to the API or scheduler for this, just looking at the code quickly, I think we'd get down to the ComputeManager._resize_instance method which calls driver.migrate_disk_and_power_off() which would raise NotImplementedError. That would revert the instance.task_state, set the migration status to 'error', record a fault (and failed instance action event record) on the instance, and reset the instance.vm_state to whatever it was originally (active or stopped). That doesn't seem so bad, so maybe we don't need anything to check for rolling upgrades while doing this.
This needs to be re-targeted for Stein.

manifests/corosync.pp.message: Interesting how to make this command idempotent.

I don't have a super effective way of not running that command it's not necessary. Because in order to check whether this is necessary, I would have to check on all the nodes, which is not possible.

However I think there are two things which make it fairly idempotent as far as state is concerned.

1. that code only runs when puppet finds out that new nodes must be added. I.e a subsequent deploy would not retrigger it.

2. If for any reason (e.g. puppet breaks right after running this resource) that resource must be re-executed, pcs host auth still succeeds. So there's no error thrown out.

This is incorrect, the previous skip still makes sense; here's why:

"snapshot_support" and "create_share_from_snapshot_support" are distinct features supported by share drivers/backends. There are drivers that allow creating snapshots, but don't allow cloning those snapshots into shares ("create_share_from_snapshot_support"). 

 

So, while those drivers you can expect to set "run_snapshot_tests=True", and "capability_create_share_from_snapshot_support=False" in your tempest configuration. The inverse of this (setting "capability_create_share_from_snapshot_support=True and "run_snapshot_tests=False") is not a valid configuration.

 

This test verifies that you're able to create shares with a snapshot, and filter only those shares - so, the skip here must be on "capability_create_share_from_snapshot_support"

For consistency we should use uri instead of url.

This name is confusing - the existence of the server_base module is an implementation detail that no operator should ever have to think about.

Is there a reason not to just call it public_auth_uri? (i.e. is there a scenario in which the endpoint that is reachable from a provisioned server is _not_ the "public" endpoint?)

If so then maybe provisioned_server_auth_uri?
yep public_auth_uri or external_auth_uri sounds good and in keystone_client section.
Went for public_auth_uri, I agree it should be in the keystone_client section.
pep8 will likely complain about this trailing space.

Also applies to bare-metal, so maybe just use 'server' here.

We should specify in the comment exactly which URI we want to see and give an example, like on line 358-359.

It's unfortunate that we have this inconsistency in meaning between auth_uri (unversioned auth URI) and public_auth_uri (a versioned Keystone endpoint URL).

This may be unavoidable, because Heat itself does not necessarily have access to the public endpoint, so it wouldn't be able to ask Keystone for the correct versioned endpoint via the public_auth_uri.

This does raise a question: is there any way of obtaining the *public* versioned Keystone endpoint given only the *internal* auth_uri? If there were then that might be a better option than adding a config option (and we could incorporate it into e.g. https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat/tree/heat/common/endpoint_utils.py#n24). 

If not then IIUC asking for the versioned endpoint in the config file is probably just how it has to be due to signal_responder's requirement of providing a v3 endpoint specifically.

The thing that springs to mind obviously here is that it is possible to query the service catalog at the cli and easily list all the endpoints "openstack endpoint list".

Therefore it should be possible to achieve the same in code.

Can we please add some sort of comment about what this is used for? e.g.

"This option should be provided when the auth_uri is not reachable from user workloads (i.e. servers provisioned using Heat). If it is not provided, auth_uri will be used instead."

stx-config/sysinv/cgts-client/cgts-client/cgtsclient/v1/helm_shell.py, def do_helm_override_update, will make parameter checking. Then send the correct value setting to sysinv-api.

If wrong user setting, it will promote with such help info.

[sysadmin@controller-0 ~(keystone_admin)]$ system helm-override-update --set conf.panko.database.event_time_to_live= panko openstack
usage: system helm-override-update [--reuse-values] [--reset-values]
                                   [--values <file_name>]
                                   [--set <commandline_overrides>]
                                   [--set-string <commandline_overrides>]
                                   <app name> <chart name> <namespace>
system helm-override-update: error: too few arguments
[sysadmin@controller-0 ~(keystone_admin)]$

The loop here is over set_overrides - and if the 'value' (from value_set.split("=") is None, then isdigit() will fail with an exception.

Also, note that it is not necessary to send via cgtsclient 'system' command, the API request could go directly to the sysinv-api enpdoint.

Actually, the fix in this version covers all the cases already. John was concerned that isdigit() will fail if it's Nonetype value, but the data passed via helm-override-update --set option is always Unicode string

ie... the split value null, None or blank in following examples are all unicode string, so will run with helm --set option.
--set conf.panko.DEFAULT.debug=
--set conf.panko.DEFAULT.debug=null
--set conf.panko.DEFAULT.debug=None

The latest patch9 works too.

It appears the case where len(keypair) != 2 is an error condition and should be raised as such.

Furthermore, is it not valid to set None to --set-string?
For such case "--set key=", len(keypair) =2, but keypair[1]="". It will be skipped. So request user must input such format "--set key=value". Otherwise such setting will be skipped.

Is it intended to skip the case that value is blank? I think we need to handle such case.

helm is able to pass blank override
ie.. helm install panko --set conf.panko.DEFAULT.debug=

And current system helm-override-update CLI is able to pass the blank value too.

nova/context.py.message:
FYI the reason we take care not overwrite the greenthread-local context here is because oslo.log uses the thread local context to log the request_id [1]. If it is overwritten by a get_admin_context or get_context call, then the request_id that could trace a request will get "hijacked" being overwritten by whatever called get_admin_context or get_context (if overwrite=True). So let's say a request to boot an instance comes in, the request_id is traceable through the services, until, for example, a periodic task calls get_admin_context(overwrite=True), then the request_id for the instance boot request will change to the new request_id that was generated by the RequestContext constructor [2] in the get_admin_context(overwrite=True) call, thus breaking the consistency of one request_id per request in the logs. (see the first bug linked below)

And request_id isn't the only issue either, if overwrite=True then anything that calls get_admin_context or get_context would cause the original auth_token, project_id, etc from the request to be overwritten. For example, project_id of the request will be overwritten to None because project_id=None here. (see the second bug linked below)

See bugs:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1773102
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1627838

I'm thinking maybe I should propose a change to add more code comments here explaining what's behind overwrite=False, to let this not be a tribal knowledge situation going forward.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.log/blob/b21efb5f7ad6aa268330f4bc3f6585bc8ba41c56/oslo_log/formatters.py#L74-L91
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.context/blob/07f068d8a2bf8420a419f806a22012ed8419d029/oslo_context/context.py#L176-L277

> I'm thinking maybe I should propose a change to add more code comments here explaining what's behind overwrite=False, to let this not be a tribal knowledge situation going forward.

Definitely.

OK, I think I need to correct myself after thinking more about efried's question in IRC about how periodic tasks should have their own thread, so how can they overwrite anything?

It's true, periodic tasks have their own threads, so I need to nix mention of periodic tasks in my above comment. Re-reading bug 1773102, it says that because of the bug, thread local variables were *not* actually local to threads and were being overwritten any time another thread created a context. So that is how periodic tasks were ever involved in any overwriting.

Since that bug has been fixed, the problem of using overwrite=True here should be limited to callers of get_admin_context and get_context in the same thread of a request only.

Note that recently someone said in a bug comment that they saw periodic tasks taking on the request_id of user-initiated requests (causing confusion in the logs):

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1835958/comments/3
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1835958/comments/7

But I don't understand how that's possible given the periodics have their own threads and I don't find evidence of it in recent gate runs. If I take a request_id for a run of a periodic task and search the rest of the compute log, I don't find other appearances of it. It would seem like the only way they could be seeing that is if they still had bug 1773102 in their environment somehow? They're running queens and the fix was backported to queens and released in 17.0.6 on 2018-09-24.
